How IFTTT Changed My Life

Apr 22, 2014
2 minute read

How many times have you used separate web applications and thought, “This is great, but it would be so much better if I could tie these guys together”?

Enjoying automation naturally leads to wanting apps to speak each other’s language. I run into this wish every single day. Fortunately, there is a cure: IFTTT (which stands for “If This, Then That”). IFTTT’s purpose is simple: create connections between applications.

TL;DR

IFTTT is a great web application and is worthy of your time.

What IFTTT Does

IFTTT utilizes up of several components:

  • Channels: a Channel is a web application that has triggers and actions. IFTTT has an enormous amount channels (and is adding more every week).
  • Triggers: a Trigger is an web-service notification that IFTTT monitors – it is the This part of “If This, Then That”. Some examples:
    • “When you take a new photo in Instagram”
    • “When I share a link in Evernote”
    • “When a new entry appears in an RSS feed”.
  • Actions: an Action is a web-service operation that occurs when a trigger fires – it is the That part of “If This, Then That”. Some examples:
    • “Create a status message in Facebook”
    • “Create a new Google Doc”
    • “Add a new file to Dropbox from a URL”.
  • Ingredients: Ingredients are chunks of data that come from a Trigger that can be given to an Action. Some examples:
    • The text from a Facebook status update
    • The URL of a Tweet
    • The title of a Microsoft OneNote document
  • Recipes: a Recipe is a completed set of a Trigger, an Action, and Ingredients.

My Recipes

Over the past few years, I have built up a collection of great IFTTT Recipes; allow me to share them.

When my Facebook profile picture changes, change my Twitter profile picture.

I love this one because it saves me time: when I update my Facebook profile picture, update my Twitter profile picture, too.

Invite my new iPhone contacts to connect on LinkedIn.

This might be a bit overzealous, but when I add a new contact to my iPhone, I like to invite that person to connect on LinkedIn.

If I tag an article with “Evernote” in Feedly, then create a note in Evernote.

With all love toward the Feedly folks, I don’t feel like paying for Feedly Pro’s Evernote integration. This recipe shortcuts this process: when I tag an article with the “Evernote” tag, it gets sent to Evernote.

If any new Feedly article is saved for later, then add it to Readability.

Once more, with all due deference to Feedly Pro, I don’t want to pay to send articles to Readability.

Send iOS notification for new IFTTT channels.

I love IFTTT and want to be notified of its every movement.

Bookmark favorite tweets.

When I mark a tweet as a favorite, save the first link it references to my Pinboard account.

Upload new Instagram photos to Flickr.

When I mark a tweet as a favorite, save the first link it references to my Pinboard account.

Others?

One set of Recipes not mentioned here are my suite of Recipes for powering Sifttter Redux.

What are your favorite IFTTT Recipes?
